we thought of is we said okay this is begging for over subscription well we

micro uh there was one size we launched it in September of 2010 had about 600 megabytes of memory a very small
instance uh and the way we designed the T1 micro was you got a very small consistent level of CPU we had a
guaranteed level that was really small but when a request came along it was really kind of targeted a at a web
server type application you would get a big burst of cap capacity where you could get kind of the full Core Power
but it was very short bursts and we really limited cuz we wanted to make sure that we didn't kind of run into these places where customers would get
inconsistent performance where you'd get kind of CPU soakers people doing kind of encoding or something like that and come
and soak up all the CPU on the box and the other people wouldn't have any available when they needed it so we
launched the t2 and uh allowed for these very short purse uh customers liked the t2s we got a lot of feedback though um

the feedback we got though was 600 megabytes is really small uh um it
doesn't even load WIndows most of the time um and uh and the short bursts were
too short they'd find you know they'd sit idle most of the time they'd try to run a process you try to you couldn't

CPU usage um uh so we learned from that we said okay we think we can do
better uh and just this last year we launched T2 so we decided okay we're going to
offer more sizes we offer we offer t2s in a one gigabyte 2 gigabyte and 4 gigabyte size so a micro small and a
medium uh but we also said what we want to do uh is let people earn CPU credits
so what the t2s do um is when your instance is sitting idle and I should I should back up there when we mean idle
it turns out when we looked at CPUs no one's instances really sit idle for 20 minutes at a time but if you measure
them at the kind of millisecond or microsc um time periods uh they'll get a
process and they'll Spike up really bit really big and what it turns out most applications want is they want the full CPU for a really short amount of time
and then they'll go idle for another couple of milliseconds and they'll Spike up again and be idle for a couple seconds and Spike up again and that's
really what the application patterns typically looked like so what we decided to do is offer people the opportunity to
give credits earn credits and a credit is basically when you spike if you're using the full core that's when you're
using it when you're idle you're kind of acre credits so we said we looked at a
lot of the usage patterns that we see in the fleet and we said we can build an instance where most of the time people
get full cores on these uh these T2 instances if they're running them steady state will give them a a relatively low
although slightly higher than before level of performance but most applic don't operate that way um and we think
that we can actually manage that um and give people a really consistent performance all of the time um for those
kind of applications that occasionally need bursts of CPU um and so we allow t2s to burst up to 3.3 GHz you get full
core access um so these are you basically get a very very powerful core
on your small instance when you need it and when you're idle you're earning credits um credits are earned uh T2
micro can earn up to six minutes of credit an hour hour um and so over a couple hours you can actually run steady
state for several minutes at a time um uh while and then go idle or you can kind of have a bunch of these little
micr bursts uh so we launched this they've been incredibly popular with customers um the performance has been
really good for the the t2s um and we've measured only 2.5% of customers ever
bump up against their credit limit so most applications that are running the t2s think they get all the cores all of
the time and they never know the difference so then we said said I wonder
if we can apply this to EBS so a couple years ago we launched provisioned iops where we have very high performing EBS

customers similarly we said I bet there's a similar use case where most people need a lot of iops and then
they'll be idle for most of the time and they need a lot lot of iops and they need to calculate and then they'll be idle um so we launched general purpose

you can imagine things like boot um small to mediumsized databases where you really want a bunch of iops for concerted periods of time but you're

uh internally we know and you guys know if you're going to operate a service well you have to measure all of
everything you have to measure metrics you have to alarm against metrics you have to look at metrics our services literally have hundreds and hundreds of
graphs that they look at um this is just a small sampling of things that we look at on ec2 and elb and on a weekly basis
all of our teams a daily basis our teams are looking at all these different number uh metrics um and trying to find
areas of their service that may not be performing um as well as they like um and hopefully finding errors before they
impact you when we do find an error um Amazon has an interesting uh policy where we
decide to be reflective and our goal is to dive deep into every single error that we find to really understand what
is the root cause one of the key things about how we make sure that we operate excellently is every time we find
something that goes wrong we want to know what that root cause is understand the impact focus on the events not just
the ones that impacted you guys but there might be impacts that never were customer visible but we know could have
led to a customer visible event had we not captured them and we really dive into those with the same level of focus
to figure out what we can do to make sure those don't happen again you start with asking why and then you ask why
again and you ask why again and of the five wise but you don't have to stop at five you continue to ask why until you
really get to the root of the problem and really understand exactly what went wrong um and What mechanisms you can
build for systems at scale to make sure that you don't have that problem again um those are the corrective actions and
our team teams across many teams across Amazon um will regularly kind of reprioritize work to make sure that we
focus on corrective actions to make sure that operations continue to go smoothly um as things scale because if there's
one thing you learn at scale is that no matter how unlikely a problem is to happen again to happen again uh it will
happen again at scale if you don't go fix the root problem so part of what we also want to
do is build mechanisms to fix these things and sometimes uh when we think about hard problems um they're not just
errors but what we really want to do uh is figure out what causes any sort of
variations inside of performance so one of the things that customers have told us um that used to be a struggle for
them is variability and performance we call that Jitter um and that's either it's Network performance it's EBS IO
performance um variability and performance of your application causes issues and causes you guys problems so
what did we do we said we need to go figure out how to solve Jitter inside of our environment well it's a very ambiguous problem you've got to go track
down Network variability you have to track down IO variability um what we did uh we established a core working group
who met every single week to track down sources of Jitter we set slas internally for us uh we set goals for us um and
over the last several years that team has been meeting every single week um focused on nothing else but making sure
that we improve Jitter and when we think about Jitter we're not looking at average performance we're not looking at the 90th percentile we're often looking
at the 49's level of performance you can see this is the TP 999 level of of Jitter performance where we're looking
at the far outliers um to make sure that we understand why we're seeing any variabilities in performance um when we
find things that we don't like we set goals and how to improve them and we have very clear owners that are going to
go drive those and solve the problems uh to improve performance for customers uh here's another great

we would um prevent uh we would provide uh up to 90% of the provisioned iops for
a customer volume at all times 99% of the time well internally we measure
ourselves to a much higher level than that um we measure the 99th percentile 99% of the time um and you can see when

above 99 internally um and as you can see when we started out we were at 92 um and we continued to iterate over time
